comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: Ah, the railway bridge at Menangle, methinks!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47572660@N08] Often confused, it is in fact the bridge over the Nepean at Penrith. Here is the picture as it stands today [http://www.flickr.com/photos/50415738@N04/5554676422/] Here is another shot of the bridge at Penrith from a another angle shortly after it was commissioned: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/29029178@N03/8026251475/in/photolist-defCW8] Here's a 1864 sketch of the Menangle Bridge, the way to tell the difference is the height of the piers on the banks. The Menagle Bridge's piers are not as high as the ones at Penrith [en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Viaduct_Menangle_NSW_1864.jpg]

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: It's the bridge which the road currently uses at Penrith.  The rail bridge has piers which are shaped like two circular columns with a wall between them.  I think they switched the road and rail bridges at some point,  not sure, but that is the bridge currently used by the road.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Read All About It! Illustrated Sydney News 15/9/1866 p.4 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/63513124

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Ministerial inspection in February 1866 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/63244040 - quite a good read (the train from Parramatta reached 40 mph!), but not this particular ocassion as the iron spans were not yet built.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Mitch, the new railway bridge (the truss bridge) was commissioned in 1907. And, as you say, at that point the original railway bridge, commissioned in 1867, became the road bridge.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Perhaps you could amend the date on your original picture to circa 1867.

comment.author: 50415738@N04
comment._content: It is named Victoria Bridge. As John Cowper said it originally carried one line of railway across the Nepean River, but also one lane of roadway. When trains would cross at the same time as horses, the horses would get spooked so the dual line rail bridge was constructed, and Victoria Bridge was converted to carry two lanes of the Great Western Highway. It is still in use today carrying local traffic, as the twin M4 Motorway bridges were constructed further up river.
